title: Twitter accused of ‘censoring Kashmir’ as one million tweets disappear
text:
Kashmir has been placed under curfew since August 5 (Picture: Rex Features)

Twitter has been accused of bowing to demands of censorship from the Indian government, after removing tweets and closing accounts relating to Kashmir.

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) said that its study showed the Indian government was undermining ‘freedom of the press and the free flow of information’ in the region, by enlisting Twitter to censor accounts.

It is also alleged that Twitter has blocked more accounts in Kashmir than in every other country combined.

It comes after Kashmir entered its 85th day of lockdown, after a curfew was imposed by the Indian government, cutting off telephone and internet services and closing schools as well as limiting public gatherings.

Hospitals have also reported a shortage of medicines for critically ill patients amid the lockdown.

The decision to place the region under curfew was made after Article 370 of the Indian constitution, which gave India’s Muslim majority region a degree of autonomy, was revoked on August 5.

Since the imposition of the curfew, Reuters reported that nearly 4,000 people had been detained by mid-September, with the crackdown on Twitter users beginning two years ago.

Twitter has been accused of undermining freedom of speech by deleting Tweets (Picture: AFP)

A CPJ analysis of data given by Twitter to Harvard University’s Berkman Klein Center and its Lumen project, showed that legal notices to the company by the Indian government, directing them to take down tweets or accounts, started to spike in August of 2017.

It is alleged that in one case, a Twitter account belonging to Kashmir Narrator, a magazine based in Jammu and Kashmir, was highlighted by the government for breaking Indian law.

Twitter is then accused of blocking locals in the region from accessing the magazine’s account.

Executive Director of Human Rights Watch Kenneth Roth tweeted: ‘The Indian government has been pressing Twitter to censor journalism and commentary emanating from Kashmir.

‘Meanwhile, “more accounts were withheld in India in the second half of 2018 than in the rest of the world combined”.

People walk past as Indian paramilitary troopers stand guard during a lockdown in Srinagar, Kashmir (Picture: AFP)

A spokesperson for Twitter said: ‘Twitter exists to serve the public conversation, including in national and regional events of political importance.

‘We’re founded on the principles of free expression and believe people have a fundamental right to share different perspectives and points of view within the boundaries of our policies, which prohibit terrorism, hateful conduct, platform manipulation, and abuse.

‘With regards to official legal requests, we’re compelled to comply with under local law, we publish actions taken twice a year in the Twitter Transparency Report for purposes of public awareness and disclosure, and also directly to the Lumen Database.’

As India’s only Muslim majority state, Kashmir was given autonomous status under Article 370 of the Indian constitution.

This meant that the region got its own constitution, a separate flag and the freedom to make laws.

However, the Indian government has revoked Kashmir’s special status, deciding to split the region into two territories governed directly by Delhi.

The territory has long been a major source of friction between India and Pakistan, with both countries laying claim to it, even fighting three wars.
